abstract: South African death-squad leader Eugene de Kock, who was convicted in 1996 for crimes committed during apartheid era, is granted parole in move toward reconciliation; many feel he does not deserve mercy but authorities say he has cooperated in investigations and that he has shown remorse; release date is not made public.
lead_paragraph: The former commander, who is also known as Prime Evil and led a notorious police force, was convicted in 1996 and sentenced to two life terms plus 212 years.

byline.contributor: Alan Cowell contributed reporting from Johannesburg.

snippet: The former commander, who is also known as Prime Evil and led a notorious police force, was convicted in 1996 and sentenced to two life terms plus 212 years.

keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
keywords.name: subject

headline.main: South Africa Grants Parole to a Death-Squad Leader
headline.print_headline: South Africa Grants Parole to a Death-Squad Leader
